attributes.name: Active Fault Lines
attributes.description:
### Overview  
  
This dataset showcases active fault traces of seismogenic concern, or areas that are capable of producing earthquakes, as of 2019. The dataset includes fault lines and a small number of relevant attributes, such as fault geometry, kinematics, and slip rates, that are useful for seismic hazard modeling and other tectonic applications.    
  
### Methodology  
  
The Global Earthquake Model (GEM) Foundation synthesizes data from a set of regional and global fault datasets. Most of the datasets are collected from external sources and built into a compilation with a Python script. One can contribute to the addition and modification of the public and open GEM Global Active Faults Database through its [GitHub](https://github.com/GEMScienceTools/gem-global-active-faults/blob/2019.0/contributing.md). For the full documentation, please click on the “Learn more” button.  
  
### Additional Information  
  
Resource Watch shows only a subset of the dataset. For access to the full dataset and additional information, click on the “Learn more” button.  
  
### Disclaimer  
  
Excerpts of this description page were taken from the source metadata.

info.name: Active Fault Lines
info.technical_title: Global Earthquake Model Global Active Fault
info.cautions: - The dataset currently covers most of the deforming continental regions on Earth with the exceptions of the Malay Archipelago, Madagascar, Canada, and a few other regions. These are to be added progressively.
info.citation: Styron, Richard. 2019. "GEMScienceTools/gem-global-active-faults: First release of 2019 (Version 2019.0)". Zenodo. http://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3376300. Accessed through Resource Watch, (date). [www.resourcewatch.org](https://www.resourcewatch.org).
info.license: Creative Commons Attribution Share Alike 4.0 International

attributes.name: Active Fault Lines
attributes.description: Global active fault lines in 2019

attributes.name: dis.006 ReliefWeb Disaster Events in the News
Current Disaster Events
attributes.description:
### Overview  
  
This dataset shows countries experiencing disaster events that are actively being monitored by ReliefWeb. These disaster events include floods, droughts, severe local storms, tropical cyclones, storm surges, tsunamis, earthquakes, wildfires, cold waves, heat waves, volcanic activity, landslides, mudslides, snow avalanches, epidemics, insect infestations, and technological disasters.
  
  

ReliefWeb is the leading humanitarian information source on global crises and disasters. ReliefWeb continuously collects the latest information on ongoing crises and monitors for emerging situations. By providing reliable and timely information, they enable humanitarian workers to make informed decisions and plan effective responses.
  
  
### Methodology  
  
ReliefWeb's editorial team monitors and collects information from more than 4,000 key sources, including humanitarian agencies at the international and local levels, governments, think tanks and research institutions, and the media. From this information, ReliefWeb editors identify and select the content that is most relevant to global humanitarian workers. For the full documentation, please click on the “Learn more” button.  
  
### Additional Information  
  
Resource Watch shows only a subset of the dataset. For access to the full dataset and additional information, click on the “Learn more” button.  
  
### Visualizing the Data  
  
Our team reformatted this dataset before displaying it on Resource Watch. See the documentation on how Resource Watch processed the data on [Github](https://github.com/resource-watch/nrt-scripts/tree/master/dis_006_reliefweb_disasters). Coordinates provided in the source data were used to map this data for display on Resource Watch.   
  
### Disclaimer  
  
Excerpts of this description page were taken from the source metadata.

info.name: Current Disaster Events
info.functions: Current and ongoing global disaster events
info.cautions:
Because ReliefWeb editors select the content that is most relevant to global humanitarian workers, not all current disasters may be reported in this dataset.
  
  

Each point is located in the center of a particular country to show that the country is currently experiencing at least one disaster event. The location of this point does not indicate the actual location of the disaster.
info.citation: OCHA/ReliefWeb. n.d. “Disasters.” Retrieved from https://reliefweb.int/. Accessed through Resource Watch, (date). [www.resourcewatch.org](https://www.resourcewatch.org).

current.description: Status of event: True or False

attributes.name: Countries Experiencing Disaster Events
attributes.description: Countries experiencing ongoing disasters that are actively being monitored by ReliefWeb. Each point is located in the center of a particular country and does not indicate where in that country the disaster occurred. The types of disasters being monitored include floods, droughts, severe local storms, tropical cyclones, storm surges, tsunamis, earthquakes, wildfires, cold waves, heat waves, volcanic activity, landslides, mudslides, snow avalanches, epidemics, insect infestations, and technological disasters.

attributes.name: Global Power Plant Database
attributes.subtitle: Global open database of power plants, created by Google/WRI/Global Energy Observatory/KTH University/University of Groningen

attributes.name: Global Power Plant Database
attributes.description:
### Overview  
  
The Global Power Plant Database is a comprehensive, open source database of power plants around the world. It centralizes power plant data to make it easier to navigate, compare, and draw insights for one’s own analysis. The database covers approximately 30,000 power plants from 164 countries and includes thermal plants (e.g., coal, gas, oil, nuclear, biomass, waste, geothermal) and renewables (e.g., hydro, wind, solar). Each power plant is geolocated, and entries contain information on plant capacity, generation, ownership, and fuel type. The database will be continuously updated as data becomes available.   
  
### Methodology  
  
The Global Power Plant Database leverages existing data sources and methodologies to build a comprehensive and open-access power sector database. The database was built entirely from open sources, which are publicly available on the internet, including data from national government agencies, reports from companies that build power plants or provide their components, data from public utilities, and information from multinational organizations. Currently the Global Power Plant Database uses more than 600 sources to create the database.  
  
### Additional Information  
  
Resource Watch shows only a subset of the dataset. For access to the full dataset and additional information, click on the “Learn more” button.  
  
### Visualizing the Data  
  
Our team reformatted this dataset before displaying it on Resource Watch. Coordinates provided in the source data were used to map this data for display on Resource Watch.   
  
### Disclaimer  
  
Excerpts of this description page were taken from the source metadata.
attributes.source: Global Energy Observatory/Google/KTH Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm/Enipedia/World Resources Institute

info.name: Global Power Plant Database

sources.source-name: KTH Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm

info.functions: A comprehensive, global, open source database of power plants
info.cautions:
The "Primary Fuel" is the fuel that has been identified to provide the largest portion of generated electricity for the plant or has been identified as the primary fuel by the data source.
For power plants that have data in multiple "Other Fuel" fields, the ordering of the fuels should not be taken to indicate any priority or preference of the fuel for operating the power plant or generating units.
Though the "Other Fuel" columns in the database are numbered sequentially from 1, the ordering is insignificant.  
  
Generation is provided at the year scale for the years 2013-2017. The generation values may correspond to a calendar year or a fiscal or regulatory year; no distinction is provided in the database.
info.citation: Global Energy Observatory, Google, KTH Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Enipedia, World Resources Institute. 2019. Global Power Plant Database v1.2.0. Published on Resource Watch (http://resourcewatch.org/) and Google Earth Engine (https://earthengine.google.com/). Accessed through Resource Watch, (date). [www.resourcewatch.org](https://www.resourcewatch.org).

owner.description: Primary, or reported, owner of the power plant

fuel1.description: Fuel used in the power plant

fuel2.description: Fuel used in the power plant

estimated_generation_gwh.description: Estimated electricity generation for 2015 in gigawatt-hours

commissioning_year.description: Year when the power plant began operations.

capacity_mw.description: Installed electrical capacity of the power plant in megawatts

fuel3.description: Fuel used in the power plant

fuel4.description: Fuel used in the power plant

gppd_idnr.description: A unique identifier assigned to this power plant

primary_fuel.description: Primary fuel used in generation of electricity

attributes.name: cit.035a.nrt Air Quality - Satellite Measurements - TROPOMI (NO₂)
Air Quality: Nitrogen Dioxide (NO₂) Satellite Measurements
attributes.description:
### Overview  
  
The Air Quality: NO₂ Satellite Measurements dataset provides global monthly averages of nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) density in the troposphere. Each value shown in the dataset represents the density of NO₂ between Earth’s surface and the top of the troposphere. The NO₂ density is reported with units of moles of NO₂ per square meter of air (mol/m²).

  
  
Nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) is one of the most common compounds in the nitrogen oxides (NOx) group. Other nitrogen oxides include nitric acid (HNO₃) and nitric oxide (NO). NO₂ is used as the indicator for the larger group of nitrogen oxides, meaning if NO₂ is present it is likely other nitrogen oxides are as well. NO₂ is primarily created by the burning of fuel, which can be from cars, trucks and buses, power plants, and off-road equipment. Breathing air with a high concentration of NO₂ can irritate airways in the human respiratory system. Acute exposures can aggravate respiratory diseases, particularly asthma, leading to respiratory symptoms, like coughing, wheezing or difficulty breathing. Longer chronic exposures to elevated concentrations of NO₂ may contribute to the development of asthma and potentially increase susceptibility to respiratory infections. People with asthma, as well as children and the elderly are generally at greater risk for the health effects of NO₂.

  
  
The dataset is made up of data collected from the Sentinel-5 Precursor (S5p) mission, a low Earth orbit polar satellite system. The S5p mission is part of the Global Monitoring of the Environment and Security (GMES/COPERNICUS) space component program headed by the European Commission (EC) in partnership with the European Space Agency (ESA). Its goal is to  provide information and services on air quality, climate, and the ozone layer. The S5p mission includes the TROPOspheric Monitoring Instrument (TROPOMI), which takes daily global observations of key atmospheric components, such as NO₂, at a 5.5 x 3.5 kilometer (km) resolution.

  
  
Resource Watch also shows TROPOMI data for [carbon monoxide (CO)](https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/Air-Quality-Measurements-TROPOMI-CO), [ozone (O₃)](https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/Air-Quality-Measurements-TROPOMI-O), and [absorbing aerosol index (AAI)](https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/Air-Quality-Measurements-TROPOMI-AER-AI). 
  
  
### Methodology  
  
The TROPOMI NO₂ dataset was created with data collected by the S5P satellite mission. The data was retrieved and analyzed using a 3 step process. 

  
  
1. Total NO₂ slant column density was determined from radiance and irradiance spectra measured by TROPOMI. It was analyzed using a Differential Optical Absorption Spectroscopy (DOAS) method. NO₂ slant column density is the amount of NO₂ found along an average path taken by photons traveling from the sun to the satellite sensor.

  
  
2. Slant column density data was then separated into stratospheric and tropospheric categories based on information coming from the satellite’s data assimilation system. Stratospheric data was then removed from the dataset.

  
  
3. Tropospheric slant column density was converted into tropospheric vertical column density and the average NO₂ density for the entire vertical column was calculated. This was determined by applying an appropriate air mass factor (AMF) and actual, daily information on the vertical distribution of NO₂ calculated by the TM5-MP global chemistry transport model. The altitude-dependent AMF used depended on the satellite geometry, terrain height, cloud fraction and height, and surface albedo.

  
  
The dataset shown on Resource Watch was mapped by the Google Earth Engine team using the [harpconvert] (https://cdn.rawgit.com/stcorp/harp/master/doc/html/harpconvert.html) tool. For more information on this conversion please see the Google Earth Engine documentation. The offline version of this data is displayed on Resource Watch, which is more complete than its near real-time counterpart, but is released on a greater delay due to the additional processing time needed. For the full documentation, please see the [source methodology](https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/technical-guides/sentinel-5p/products-algorithms) associated with the “Nitrogen Dioxide (NO₂) Total Column”.  
  
### Additional Information  
  
Resource Watch also shows TROPOMI data for [carbon monoxide (CO)](https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/Air-Quality-Measurements-TROPOMI-CO), [ozone (O₃)](https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/Air-Quality-Measurements-TROPOMI-O), and [absorbing aerosol index (AAI)] (https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/Air-Quality-Measurements-TROPOMI-AER-AI).
  
  
Resource Watch shows only a subset of the dataset. Additional data for formaldehyde (CH₂O), sulphur dioxide (SO₂), methane (CH₄) and clouds are available from the data provider. Both a near real-time and an offline version of each of these compounds are available. Please see the [Google Earth Engine data catalog](https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/tags/tropomi) to access this data. For access to the full dataset and additional information, click on the “Learn more” button.
  
  
### Visualizing the Data  
  
Our team reformatted this dataset before displaying it on Resource Watch. See the documentation on how Resource Watch processed the data on [Github](https://github.com/resource-watch/nrt-scripts/tree/master/cit_035_tropomi_atmospheric_chemistry_model).  
  
### Disclaimer  
  
Excerpts of this description page were taken from the source metadata.

info.name: Air Quality: Nitrogen Dioxide (NO₂) Satellite Measurements
info.technical_title: Sentinel 5 Precursor Tropospheric Monitoring Instrument (S5P/TROPOMI) Offline (OFFL) Level 3 (L3) Nitrogen Dioxide (NO₂)
info.functions: Average monthly density of nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) in the troposphere
info.cautions:
- The current surface albedo climatology used has a spatial resolution of 0.5° x 0.5° (approximately 55 x 55 km), which is coarse compared to the much higher spatial resolution used by S5p TROPOMI of 3.5 x 5.5 km. As a consequence, the albedo grid affects the NO₂ column products quality, especially in coastal areas.

  
  
- In general, TROPOMI underestimates the tropospheric NO₂ densities at polluted sites. The median negative biases of the daily comparisons are generally less than 50% (the product requirement for tropospheric NO₂), but can be quite variable depending on station and NO₂ level. 

  
  
- Good coherence is found between TROPOMI and Multi Axis Differential Absorption Spectroscopy (MAX-DOAS) NO₂ datasets with a correlation coefficient of 0.84.
  
  
- For more information on the data quality, please see the [product readme file](https://sentinel.esa.int/documents/247904/3541451/Sentinel-5P-Nitrogen-Dioxide-Level-2-Product-Readme-File).
info.citation: European Space Agency. 2018. ESA Sentinel-5P TROPOMI L3 products. Accessed through Resource Watch, (date). [www.resourcewatch.org](https://www.resourcewatch.org).

attributes.name: April 15, 2021 - May 15, 2021 Average Tropospheric Nitrogen Dioxide (NO₂) (mol/m², millionths)
attributes.description: Density of nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) in the troposphere, expressed in terms of millionths of a mole of NO₂ per square meter of air (mol/m², millionths). This data layer contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data, in which all data from the most recent 30-day period has been averaged.

body.sldValue: <RasterSymbolizer>     <ColorMap type="ramp" extended="false" > '<ColorMapEntry color="#000003" quantity="-1"/>'+'<ColorMapEntry color="#000003" quantity="0.000005"/>' + '<ColorMapEntry color="#550F6D" quantity="0.00001"/>' + '<ColorMapEntry color="#BA3655" quantity="0.00003"/>' +  '<ColorMapEntry color="#F98C09" quantity="0.0001"/>' + '<ColorMapEntry color="#FCFEA4" quantity="0.0003"/> </ColorMap>   </RasterSymbolizer>

config.url: https://api.resourcewatch.org/v1/query/b75d8398-34f2-447d-832d-ea570451995a?sql=select last(tropospheric_NO2_column_number_density) as x from 'projects/resource-watch-gee/cit_035_tropomi_atmospheric_chemistry_model_30day_avg/NO2/cit_035_tropomi_atmospheric_chemistry_model_30day_avg_NO2_2021-05-15' where system:time_start >= 1533448800000 and ST_INTERSECTS(ST_SetSRID(ST_GeomFromGeoJSON('{"type":"Point","coordinates":[{{lng}},{{lat}}]}'),4326),the_geom)

pulseConfig.url: https://api.resourcewatch.org/v1/query/b75d8398-34f2-447d-832d-ea570451995a?sql=select last(tropospheric_NO2_column_number_density) as x from 'projects/resource-watch-gee/cit_035_tropomi_atmospheric_chemistry_model_30day_avg/NO2/cit_035_tropomi_atmospheric_chemistry_model_30day_avg_NO2_2021-05-15' where system:time_start >= 1533448800000 and ST_INTERSECTS(ST_SetSRID(ST_GeomFromGeoJSON('{"type":"Point","coordinates":{{point}}}'),4326),the_geom)

attributes.name: Soil Carbon Stocks
attributes.description: The International Soil Reference and Information Centre - World Soil Information (ISRIC-WIS) uses machine learning techniques to develop global maps of soil properties at various soil depths, as well as characterizing bedrock depth. Soil organic carbon stocks are reported in decigrams per kilogram for six standard depth intervals: depths of 0-5 cm, 5-15 cm, 15-30 cm, 30-60 cm, 60-100 cm, and 100-200 cm. Soil organic carbon stocks are important because they are correlated with the productive capacity of land to generate food and other plant life. Soil property estimates are generated using machine learning techniques that combine soil samples, expert opinion, and remote-sensing data. It takes as inputs soil observations from about 240,000 locations worldwide and over 400 global environmental covariates describing vegetation, terrain morphology, climate, geology and hydrology. The quantification of spatial uncertainty for this dataset showed metrics in line with previous studies at global, continental, or large region scale. The qualitative evaluation showed that coarse scale patterns are well reproduced.

info.name: Soil Carbon Stocks
info.functions: High-resolution maps of soil carbon stocks, which contribute to the productivity of agriculture
info.cautions:
- Not all land areas are uniformly represented in 240,000 samples used to train the sample data and therefore some areas and soil types will be better modeled than others.
  
  
- The spatial uncertainty at global scale highlighted the need for more soil observations, especially in high latitude regions.
info.citation: de Sousa, L. M., Poggio, L., Batjes, N. H., Heuvelink, G. B. M., Kempen, B., Riberio, E., and Rossiter, D. (in review, 2020) "SoilGrids 2.0: producing quality-assessed soil information for the globe", SOIL Discuss. [preprint], https://doi.org/10.5194/soil-2020-65. Accessed through Resource Watch, (date). [www.resourcewatch.org](https://www.resourcewatch.org).

attributes.name: Soil Organic Carbon Stocks from 0-5 cm of Soil Depth (dg/kg)
attributes.description: High-resolution map of soil carbon stocks, which contribute to the productivity of agriculture. Carbon stocks from the top 0-5 cm of soil are shown in decigrams per kilogram (dg/kg) for 1905-2016.

attributes.name: Soil Organic Carbon Stocks from 60-100 cm of Soil Depth (dg/kg)
attributes.description: High-resolution map of soil carbon stocks, which contribute to the productivity of agriculture. Carbon stocks from the top 60-100 cm of soil are shown in decigrams per kilogram (dg/kg) for 1905-2016.

body.sldValue: <RasterSymbolizer><ChannelSelection>   <GrayChannel>   <SourceChannelName>soc_60-100cm_mean</SourceChannelName>        </GrayChannel>        </ChannelSelection> <ColorMap type="ramp" extended="false" ><ColorMapEntry color="#f6e8c3" quantity="50" label="" opacity="1" /><ColorMapEntry color="#dfc27d" quantity="100" label="" opacity="1" /><ColorMapEntry color="#bf812d" quantity="200" label="" /><ColorMapEntry color="#8c510a" quantity="500" label="" /><ColorMapEntry color="#543005" quantity="4000" label="" /></ColorMap></RasterSymbolizer>

config.url: https://api.resourcewatch.org/v1/query/c5a62289-bdc8-4821-83f0-6f05e3d36bdc?sql=select st_summarystats(rast, 'soc_60-100cm_mean', false) as x from 'projects/soilgrids-isric/soc_mean' where ST_INTERSECTS(ST_SetSRID(ST_GeomFromGeoJSON('{"type":"Point","coordinates":[{{lng}},{{lat}}]}'),4326),the_geom)

attributes.name: Soil Organic Carbon Stocks from 100-200 cm of Soil Depth (dg/kg)
attributes.description: High-resolution map of soil carbon stocks, which contribute to the productivity of agriculture. Carbon stocks from the top 100-200 cm of soil are shown in decigrams per kilogram (dg/kg) for 1905-2016.

body.sldValue: <RasterSymbolizer><ChannelSelection>   <GrayChannel>   <SourceChannelName>soc_100-200cm_mean</SourceChannelName>        </GrayChannel>        </ChannelSelection> <ColorMap type="ramp" extended="false" ><ColorMapEntry color="#f6e8c3" quantity="50" label="" opacity="1" /><ColorMapEntry color="#dfc27d" quantity="100" label="" opacity="1" /><ColorMapEntry color="#bf812d" quantity="200" label="" /><ColorMapEntry color="#8c510a" quantity="500" label="" /><ColorMapEntry color="#543005" quantity="4000" label="" /></ColorMap></RasterSymbolizer>

config.url: https://api.resourcewatch.org/v1/query/c5a62289-bdc8-4821-83f0-6f05e3d36bdc?sql=select st_summarystats(rast, 'soc_100-200cm_mean', false) as x from 'projects/soilgrids-isric/soc_mean' where ST_INTERSECTS(ST_SetSRID(ST_GeomFromGeoJSON('{"type":"Point","coordinates":[{{lng}},{{lat}}]}'),4326),the_geom)
